entry.title: Day 8 AI vs ML vs DL
entry.summary:
AI vs ML vs DL! How are they different?

👉 AI - Machines that can learn, reason, and act for themselves

👉 ML - Looking for patterns in data using statistical algorithms

👉 DL - Technique to perform ML inspired by our brain's network of neurons  

What is #ArtificialIntelligence?

It is essentially refers to machines that can learn, reason, and act for themselves. This flowchart and the blog by @_KarenHao clarifies it very well!

 

technologyreview.com/2018/11/10/139…

 

What is AI? We drew you a flowchart to work it out

What is AI, exactly? The question may seem basic, but the answer is kind of complicated. In the broadest sense, AI refers to machines that can learn, reason, and act for themselves. They can make thei…

https://www.technologyreview.com/2018/11/10/139137/is-this-ai-we-drew-you-a-flowchart-to-work-it-out/

https://www.technologyreview.com/2018/11/10/139137/is-this-ai-we-drew-you-a-flowchart-to-work-it-out/

 

 

I played with Teachable Machine today and created a #nocode classification model in less than 5 mins! It's a web-based tool making #machinelearning models fast, easy, and accessible to everyone.

 

See how I created a yoga pose classification model 🧵👇

Video 

🤔 How to use Teachable Machines?

📌Gather data (upload it or use webcam/microphone)

📌Train model (in the web interface)

📌Export the model (use it in your app)

 

🤔 What type of data can I use to train the model?

🖼 Images

🔊 Sounds

🧘‍♀️ Poses

 

Now, get out of your chair 🪑 and try out my yoga 🧘‍♀️ pose classification model with any of these poses:

📌 Goddess

📌 Warrior2

📌 Tree

📌 Downdog

 

Here is my model 👉 teachablemachine.withgoogle.com/models/vkzpnwt…

#31DaysofML 

Teachable Machine

Train a computer to recognize your own images, sounds, & poses. A fast, easy way to create machine learning models for your sites, apps, and more – no expertise or coding required.

https://teachablemachine.withgoogle.com/models/vkzpnwtIQ/

entry.title: Day 7 Things to Remeber
entry.summary: Since its Day 10 of #31DaysofML it's perfect to discuss 1️⃣0️⃣ things that can go wrong with #MachineLearning Projects and what you can do about it! I watched this amazing presentation by @kweinmeister that sums it all up 1️⃣ You aren't solving the right problem ❓What's the goal of your ML…
entry.content:
Since its Day 10 of #31DaysofML it's perfect to discuss 1️⃣0️⃣ things that can go wrong with #MachineLearning Projects and what you can do about it!

 

I watched this amazing presentation by @kweinmeister that sums it all up

1️⃣ You aren't solving the right problem

❓What's the goal of your ML model?

❓How do you assess if your model is "good" or "bad"?

❓What's your baseline?

👉 Focus on a long-term mission with maximum impact

👉 Ensure that your problem is a good fit for ML

2️⃣ Jumping into development without a prototype

👉 ML project is an iterative process

👉 Start with simple model & continue to refine it until you've reached your goal

👉 Quick prototype can tell a lot about hidden requirements, implementation challenges, scope, etc

3️⃣ Model training can take a long time

👉 When your team is trying to rapidly iterate on new ideas and techniques, training time can slow down projects and get in the way of innovation.

👉 Use GPU's, TPUs to speed up training

👉 Use serverless training methods

4️⃣ You have an imbalanced dataset

❓ How can you balance accuracy across each class?

👉 Weighting each class

👉 Oversampling and undersampling

👉 Generating synthetic data

Here's a tutorial to checkout tensorflow.org/tutorials/stru…

 

 

Classification on imbalanced data  |  TensorFlow Core

https://tensorflow.org/tutorials/structured_data/imbalanced_data

5️⃣ Your model's accuracy is not good enough

👉 Include more varied training data

👉 Feature engineering

👉 Try different model architectures, hyper-parameter tuning & ensembles

👉 Remove features that may be causing overfitting, start with a smaller model & add features slowly

6️⃣ Your model doesn't serve all of your users well

"Fairness is the process of understanding bias introduced by your data & ensuring your model provides equitable predictions across all demographic groups"

- read more 👉 bit.ly/2Ly9wMM

 

#31DaysofML

Building ML models for everyone: understanding fairness in machine learning

Learn why implementing ML fairness into an ML workflow is so important, and see tools and techniques to get started.

https://bit.ly/2Ly9wMM

7️⃣ It's unclear how your model works

👉 How will you be able to explain how your model makes predictions?

👉 Under what conditions does the model perform best and most consistently?

👉 Does it have blind spots? If so, where?

Read about Explainable AI 👉

 

Explainable AI  |  Google Cloud

Deploy interpretable and inclusive machine learning models with Explainable AI, tools and frameworks designed to instill user trust.

https://bit.ly/3aFJdwx

 

8️⃣ You could accidentally push a bad model into production

👉 Create ML pipeline to run same steps in same environment every time with a trigger/schedule

👉 Include steps - Data validation, Model evaluation, Conditional deployment

👉 Track pipeline runs & artifacts

 

9️⃣ Your model accuracy is drifting downward

See image 👇

 

1️⃣0️⃣ Model inference isn't scaling well in production

👉 Choose the right deployment tools that can scale

👉 Serve online endpoints for low-latency predictions, or predictions on massive batches of data

👉 Scale automatically based on your traffic

entry.title: Day 6 Learning Rate
entry.summary:
📖 Learning Rate 📖 Also known as Step size

It's a scalar that is multiplied with gradient vector (which has the direction & magnitude) to provide the next value on the loss curve

 

👉 Smaller the learning rate the longer it will take to find the lowest loss value

👉 Large learning rate could overshoot the minimum

👉 You the learning rate to be just right (Goldilock's learning rate) to get the convergence value efficiently

Learning rate is one of the "Hyper parameters" that we tweak in machine learning algorithms. This is to tune the learning rate to efficiently get to the lowest loss value. There are more hyper parameters which we will get to later...
entry.content:
📖 Learning Rate 📖 Also known as Step size

It's a scalar that is multiplied with gradient vector (which has the direction & magnitude) to provide the next value on the loss curve

 

👉 Smaller the learning rate the longer it will take to find the lowest loss value

👉 Large learning rate could overshoot the minimum

👉 You the learning rate to be just right (Goldilock's learning rate) to get the convergence value efficiently

Learning rate is one of the "Hyper parameters" that we tweak in machine learning algorithms. This is to tune the learning rate to efficiently get to the lowest loss value. There are more hyper parameters which we will get to later...

💁‍♀️ I thought today I would share a tip that has helped me in my #MachineLearning journey

💡The best way to learn ML is to pick a problem that you feel excited about & let it guide your learning path. Don't worry about the terms or tools, it's all secondary

 

Here's an example. Few weeks ago I wanted to live translate an episode of @GCPPodcast. The first question I asked myself was:

🤔 Does any video/audio translation API already exist?

🔹 If so - I would give that a try

🔹 If not, I would create it from scratch

 

Next, I started digging into the Media Translation API which would translate audio & video data.

My point is:

📌 You don't always need to create a model

📌 Save yourself time & resources by using the models that already exist (if they server your purpose)

 

Media translation API served my purpose. It was:

🔹 Easy to setup

🔹 Provided real-time translations

🔹 Accuracy was high

🔹 I did not have to use Speech-to-Text & Translation models separately

 

Read more 👉 bit.ly/gcp_mta

 

 

Video

Media Translation  |  Google Cloud

With Google Cloud's Media Translation API, you can add real-time audio translation directly to your content and applications in a seamless manner.

https://bit.ly/gcp_mta

 

If you are convinced that any existing models/API don't serve your needs then look at creating custom models. Even then choose easier paths such as AutoML which allows you to upload your data and automate the training for you. More on this later... 👋

entry.title: Day 5 Trainning &Loss, Reducing Loss
entry.summary:
🕹 Training & Loss 🕹

In supervised learning training a model means learning good values for weights & bias from labelled examples. In doing so it attempts to find a model that minimises loss. Process is called empirical risk minimisation

 

📌 Loss indicates how bad model's prediction was on an example

📌 Loss = 0 if the model's prediction is perfect otherwise it's greater.

📌 Goal of training is to find weights & biases that have low loss, on average, across data set

Squared loss or L2 loss is a popular Loss function that aggregates the individual losses

L2 loss for a single example = (observation - prediction)^2

Mean square error (MSE) is the average squared loss per example over the whole data set. To calculate MSE, sum up all the squared losses for individual examples and then divide by the number of examples. It looks like this 👇

Here is a fun read on loss function by @quaesita 👉 bit.ly/quaesita_emper…

 

Machine learning — Is the emperor wearing clothes? | Hacker Noon

https://bit.ly/quaesita_emperor
entry.content:
🕹 Training & Loss 🕹

In supervised learning training a model means learning good values for weights & bias from labelled examples. In doing so it attempts to find a model that minimises loss. Process is called empirical risk minimisation

 

📌 Loss indicates how bad model's prediction was on an example

📌 Loss = 0 if the model's prediction is perfect otherwise it's greater.

📌 Goal of training is to find weights & biases that have low loss, on average, across data set

Squared loss or L2 loss is a popular Loss function that aggregates the individual losses

L2 loss for a single example = (observation - prediction)^2

Mean square error (MSE) is the average squared loss per example over the whole data set. To calculate MSE, sum up all the squared losses for individual examples and then divide by the number of examples. It looks like this 👇

Here is a fun read on loss function by @quaesita 👉 bit.ly/quaesita_emper…

 

Machine learning — Is the emperor wearing clothes? | Hacker Noon

https://bit.ly/quaesita_emperor

 

⬇️ Reducing Loss ⬇️

An iterative process of choosing model parameters that minimise loss

👉 Loss function is how we compute loss

👉 Loss function curve is convex for linear regression

 

Calculating loss for every value of W isn't efficient: most common way is called gradient descent

👉 Start with any value of w, b (weights & biases)

👉 Keep going until overall loss stops changing or changes slowly

👉 That point is called convergence

As you probably already guessed, gradient is a vector with:

👉 Direction

👉 Magnitude

Gradient descent algorithms multiply the gradient by a scalar known as the learning rate (or step size) to determine the next point.

 

Here are a few resources I have used for this thread:

👉 developers.google.com/machine-learni…

👉 bit.ly/quaesita_emper…

 

 

Reducing Loss: Gradient Descent  |  Machine Learning Crash Course

https://developers.google.com/machine-learning/crash-course/reducing-loss/gradient-descent

Machine learning — Is the emperor wearing clothes? | Hacker Noon

https://bit.ly/quaesita_emperor

entry.title: Day 4 Unsupervised Learning
entry.summary: Unsupervised learning Input data is unlabeled & the program learns to recognize the inherent patterns in the input data Eg: Data across few people's eating habits Model input =🍎🍊🍊 Model output = cluster of vegetarian/vegan When is unsupervised learning used? 🔸 On large datasets where annotating…
entry.content:
Unsupervised learning

 

Input data is unlabeled & the program learns to recognize the inherent patterns in the input data

Eg: Data across few people's eating habits

Model input =🍎🍊🍊

Model output = cluster of vegetarian/vegan

 

When is unsupervised learning used?

🔸 On large datasets where annotating (labeling) data is costly

🔸 When we don't know how many classes might exist in the data

🔸 Cluster the data to apply classification on the individual clusters

 

has demystified unsupervised learning here 👉

Unsupervised learning demystified | Hacker Noon

https://bit.ly/quaesita_unsupervised



Common types of unsupervised learning:

🔹 Clustering - divide the data by similarity

📌 Eg: Target marketing, Customer recommendation

🔹 Dimensionality reduction - Find wider dependencies

📌 Eg: Big data visualizations, structure discovery



Most used clustering algorithms:

👉 Centroid-based Clustering - k-means

👉 Density-based Clustering

👉 Distribution-based Clustering - Gaussian distributions

👉 Hierarchical Clustering 

 

👉 Centroid-based Clustering organizes the data into non-hierarchical clusters

🔹 These algorithms are efficient but sensitive to initial conditions and outliers.

🔹 k-means is the most widely-used centroid-based clustering algorithm which is efficient, effective, & simple

 

6/8

👉 Density-based clustering connects areas of high example density into clusters.

🔹 Allows for arbitrary-shaped distributions as long as dense areas can be connected

🔹 These algorithms have difficulty with data of varying densities & high dimensions

 

👉 Distribution-based clustering assumes data is composed of distributions

🔹 such as Gaussian distributions

🔹 As distance from the distribution's center increases, the probability that a point belongs to the distribution decreases

 

👉 Hierarchical Clustering

🔹 Creates a tree of clusters

🔹 Well suited to hierarchical data, such as taxonomies

🔹 Advantage: Any number of clusters can be chosen by cutting the tree at the right level

Resource:

Machine Learning Crash Course  |  Google Developers

https://bit.ly/gcp_ml

entry.title: 💁Day 3 Supervised Learning
entry.summary:
There are different types of learning models. These 4 are the most common that you usually come across. 

 

  • Supervised
  • Unsupervised
  • Semi-supervised
  • Reinforcement



  • Supervised learning - Applications in which the training data is examples of the input vectors along with their corresponding target vectors

 

2 main types: 

 

Classification: Predicting a class label

Regression: Predicting a numerical label

  • Unsupervised learning is using a model to describe or extract relationships in data. Operates on only the input data without target variables

 

2 main types: 

 

Clustering: Finding groups in data

Density Estimation: Summarizing distribution of data

  • Semi-supervised - training data contains very few labeled examples & large number of unlabeled examples. 

 

The goal is to make effective use of all of the available data. 

A mixture of supervised & unsupervised methods are used.

  • Reinforcement learning - an agent operates in an environment & learns to operate using feedback.

There's no fixed training dataset, just a set of goals that an agent is set to achieve & there is a feedback loop between the learning system and its experiences.
entry.content:
There are different types of learning models. These 4 are the most common that you usually come across. 

 

  • Supervised
  • Unsupervised
  • Semi-supervised
  • Reinforcement



  • Supervised learning - Applications in which the training data is examples of the input vectors along with their corresponding target vectors

 

2 main types: 

 

Classification: Predicting a class label

Regression: Predicting a numerical label

  • Unsupervised learning is using a model to describe or extract relationships in data. Operates on only the input data without target variables

 

2 main types: 

 

Clustering: Finding groups in data

Density Estimation: Summarizing distribution of data

  • Semi-supervised - training data contains very few labeled examples & large number of unlabeled examples. 

 

The goal is to make effective use of all of the available data. 

A mixture of supervised & unsupervised methods are used.

  • Reinforcement learning - an agent operates in an environment & learns to operate using feedback.

There's no fixed training dataset, just a set of goals that an agent is set to achieve & there is a feedback loop between the learning system and its experiences.

Supervised learning

 

Input data is labeled & the program learns to predict the output based on the input examples

Model input

Image =🐒🐘🐕

label = dog,monkey,cat,dog

Model prediction input

Image =🐒

Model output  =  It's a monkey! 🐒

 

2 types of supervised learning

 

Regression model predicts continuous values

 

Value of house in LA?

What's the probability of stock value to rise?

Classification model predicts discrete values

 

Is this image cat or dog?

Is this email spam?

Regression is form of predictive analysis. It is used for:

Forecasting - estimate growth in sales

Time-series - closing value of stock exchange

Finding cause effect relationships - effect of price change on sales

most common regression types are:

Linear Regression - Establishes a relationship between dependent variable (Y) and one or more independent variables (X) using a best fit straight line

Logistic Regression - Used to find probability of an event

Logistic regression estimates probability as output which we can use in 2 ways:

"As is" - probability that a dog will bark at night eg: 0.06

Converted to a binary category - for a classification problem. "Email is a spam or not" == 0 or 1

Classification models predicts the class to which input data elements belongs. It is best used when the output has finite and discrete values.

 

Email is spam or not

Student will pass an exam or now

 

Classification Algorithms

 

  • Linear Models (binary)
  • Logistic Regression
  • Support Vector Machines
  • Nonlinear models (multi-class)
  • K-nearest Neighbors (KNN)
  • Kernel Support Vector Machines (SVM)
  • Naïve Bayes
  • Decision Tree
  • Random Forest



(Two common Regression Types)

https://twitter.com/i/status/1357947133916155907

entry.title: 💁Day 2 Labels
entry.summary: Let's explore #MachineLearning terms for supervised learning: Models - defines the relationship between features & label. Eg: The y variable in simple linear regression. The label could be the future price of wheat, the kind of animal shown in a picture, the meaning of an…
entry.content:
Let's explore #MachineLearning terms for supervised learning:

  • Labels - the thing we're predicting
  • Features - an input variable
  • Examples - particular instance of data (Labeled/Unlabeled)

Models - defines the relationship between features & label.

 

  • Labels - the thing we're predicting

 

Eg: The y variable in simple linear regression. The label could be the future price of wheat, the kind of animal shown in a picture, the meaning of an audio clip, or just about anything.

 

  • Features - an input variable x in linear regression. 

 

A simple ML project might use 1 feature X, while a sophisticated project could use millions of features X1, X2, ..... Xn

 

Eg: In the spam detector, features could be:

Words in email

Sender's address

Time

Some phrase

 

  • Examples - a particular instance of data (X)

is a vector

Labeled - includes both feature(s) & labels

Unlabeled - contains features but not labels

Model is trained on labeled examples & is used to predict the label on unlabeled examples.

  • Models - defines the relationship between features & label.

There are 2 phases of a model's life:

Training - creating/learning the model from labeled examples

Inference - applying the trained model to unlabeled examples.

entry.title: Day 1 Machine Learning
entry.summary: ⚡Let's go Day 1 of #31DaysofML 🤔What is #MachineLearning? 📊ML = Using data to answer questions! Using data = Training Answer questions = Predictions Let's keep going… 1.Collect Data The Quantity & quality of your data dictate how accurate our model is The outcome of…
entry.content:
⚡Let's go Day 1 of #31DaysofML 


🤔What is #MachineLearning?


📊ML = Using data to answer questions! 

Using data = Training

Answer questions = Predictions


Let's keep going…


1.Collect Data

The Quantity & quality of your data dictate how accurate our model is

The outcome of this step is usually a table with some values (features)

If you want to use pre-collected data - get it from sources such as Kaggle or BigQuery Public Datasets 


2.Prepare Data

Wrangle data and prepare it for training 

Split data into training, test, and evaluation sets

Clean data - correct errors, missing values, normalize

3.Choose a model

These 4 are the most common that you usually come across. 

  • Supervised
  • Unsupervised
  • Semi-supervised
  • Reinforcement

4.Train the Model

Goal = make a prediction correctly as often as possible

Depends on the learning method chosen in step 3

Eg: Linear regression algorithm would learn values for weights & biases in y = mx + b

💯Each iteration of the process is a training step


5.Evaluate the Model


Test the model against unseen data (usually 20% of data is set aside for this)

Use some metric or combination of metrics to "measure" the objective performance of the model


6.Parameter Tuning - 

Also called Hyper parameter Tuning 

Tune model parameters for improved performance. 

These include learning rate, training steps, etc

entry.title: How To Install And Run AppImage on Linux
entry.summary: Installing AppImage on your Linux System… Linux has a number of ways to install software and applications thanks to how flexible Linux has become and the open source community behind it. One of the ways of installing software on Linux is using App Image.
entry.content:
Installing AppImage on your Linux System…

Linux has a number of ways to install software and applications thanks to how flexible Linux has become and the open source community behind it.

One of the ways of installing software on Linux is using App Image.
Whats App Image?

Whats AppImage?

AppImage is a universal software package format that can be installed on Linux without going through the traditional way of installation. It doesn't require any root permission to install the software.
To install An AppImage, all you need to do is make it executable and run it. It is a compressed image with all the dependencies and libraries needed to run the desired software.

So there is no extraction, no installation needed. You can uninstall it by deleting it. Just compare it to .exe in Windows that can run without installing it.

Some notable features of App Image are:

  • It can run on various different Linux distributions
  • There’s no need for installing and compiling software
  • Portability — It can run on live disks
  • Software is uninstalled just by deleting the AppImage file

How to Install and Run AppImage?

The good thing about AppImages is that you don’t have to actually install the app, just run it. So how do you do this? It’s actually quite simple, first of all, download the app image. Then I will show you in two methods.

Using Properties

Right click on the AppImage file, click on Properties. Click on Permissions and click on Allow executing the file as a program.

Using Terminal

Open any Terminal of your choice, head over to the app image directory and run: 

chmod u+x   <AppImageFile>

Then you can now double click to run it.
That’s all.
